January 16, 1958
Mr. Kenneth Harwood, Chairman
Telecommunications
University of Southern California
University Park
Los Angeles, California
Dear Ken:
I ms extremely disappointed in the quality of the applicants
for research grants in aid. In ray opinion, the only one really
deserving of aid is the applicant from Washington. Sven here, 1 am
not sure that this is being done in the best possible way. 1 would
certainly place him first, however, and give him the entire $500.00
which he requested. The hypothesis to be tested by this study is
certainly the most meaningful of any in these applications.
X would place the Minnesota application second. X hesitate to
do this for two reasons: (1) X don't believe that this study is of
much general value to educational broadcasting (though more so than
most of these proposed) and (2) X fear that some MASS members may
feel that bias was operating due to the fact that Faulu is president
of the organization. Nonetheless, the rationale, the procedures,
etc. have been much better thought out in this proposal than in most
of the others and this deserves consideration. I would not give him
the full $500. Xt seems to me that his staff could do much of the
work — as most stations do in such studies. X would not go more
than $300.00 for postage and supplies and some clerical help. This
$300.00, however, should be on the condition that the study be done
as proposed.
Because of the quality of most of these proposals, X would place
Ed Browne's request third — his request for $100.00 to help defray
the expenses of his completed study.
X am somewhat tempted to eay that X would go no further than
this, that none of the others are worth contributing to at all. X
am not sure that this is wise, however, if we are trying to build a
research interest and function into the NAEB.
